stories.headline: Ferguson signs $9 billion in new taxes to fund state budget
stories.summary: Governor Bob Ferguson signed a state operating budget that increases taxes on businesses and wealthy individuals to boost state spending by roughly $9 billion over the next four years. This budget aims to raise money for social services, state workers, and other public needs despite a somewhat hawkish approach by Ferguson who rejected a wealth tax proposed by Democrats.

stories.headline: Trump pressures divided House Republicans to fall in line behind his big tax cuts bill
stories.summary: President Donald Trump urged House Republicans to unite and support his big tax cuts bill, warning of the risk of failure without full support. He used strong language to encourage party unity, criticized dissenters, and emphasized his leadership role while meetings and negotiations continued amid division within the party on the proposal.

stories.headline: 'Tone-deaf' Seattle earplug proposal gets mixed reaction
stories.summary: A proposal concerning Seattle earplugs has received mixed reactions from the public and stakeholders, with some viewing it as tone-deaf. The details of the proposed measures and the aspects that caused divided opinions remain a topic of local discussion.

stories.headline: Kraken still seeking coach, as prominent candidates dwindle
stories.summary: The Seattle Kraken hockey team continues its search for a new coach amid diminishing prospects as top candidates decline interest. This ongoing coaching search has sparked speculation about the future leadership direction of the team.

stories.headline: ICE arrests at immigration court trigger new fear
stories.summary: Immigration court hearings witnessed unusual arrests by ICE, including two men and one woman taken into custody in handcuffs and waist shackles. This has raised concerns about a new tactic by the Trump administration to expedite deportations by targeting immigration court proceedings, sparking fears among immigrant advocacy groups and increased scrutiny of enforcement methods.

stories.headline: New Trump policy limits who can get COVID-19 vaccinations
stories.summary: The Trump administration has announced a new policy to limit approval for seasonal COVID-19 vaccinations to seniors and others at high risk, based on new standards from the Food and Drug Administration. The policy aims to streamline vaccine availability for adults 65 and older and others with high-risk health conditions, but it has raised questions and pushback from local scientists about stricter rules and availability for others.

stories.headline: Trump taps space general to build Golden Dome by end of his term
stories.summary: President Trump has selected the architecture for his Golden Dome missile shield and appointed Gen. Michael A. Guetlein to oversee its development. The Golden Dome will feature open architecture with multiple defense capabilities including space-based interceptors and cutting-edge missile defense technologies. The system aims to be operational by the end of Mr. Trump's term and will enhance the country's national missile defense.

stories.headline: Jailbreak sparks furor over Soros-funded sheriff, lax oversight
stories.summary: Louisiana officials face criticism after a jailbreak involving 10 violent inmates at a facility overseen by Orleans Parish Sheriff Susan Hutson, who was appointed with backing from George Soros. Questions about lax oversight and the sheriff's responsibility have been raised following the incident where inmates escaped by cutting through a jail wall and managing to evade guards, highlighting security failures and administrative issues.

stories.headline: Medicaid, SALT stall House unity on 'big, beautiful bill'
stories.summary: President Trump's Medicaid and state and local tax deduction (SALT) proposals have caused division within the House, delaying progress on the 'big, beautiful bill.' Republican leaders, wary of losing more votes, opposed the current version, while some moderate Republicans suggested delaying the vote. This standoff reflects broader challenges in passing comprehensive legislation amid internal party disagreements.

stories.headline: Medicaid cuts targeted to work mandates, illegals crackdown
stories.summary: Republicans are proposing significant Medicaid spending cuts aimed at imposing work requirements and reducing benefits for illegal immigrants. The plan would save $715 billion and limit access to Medicaid to those legally in the U.S., potentially impacting millions including 1.4 million illegal immigrants. The proposal aligns Medicaid recipients with stricter requirements for benefits and aims to tighten eligibility.
people: House Energy and Commerce Committee Chairman Brett Guthrie

stories.headline: Trump's plea to Republican holdouts falls flat
stories.summary: President Trump's appeal to House Republicans to support his 'big, beautiful bill' met resistance and was largely ignored during congressional discussions. House Republicans largely opposed the current version of the bill, with leaders unwilling to lose more votes. Key figures like Rep. Andrew Garbarino and Rep. Thomas Massie expressed skepticism and reluctance to back the bill, leading to ongoing negotiations and an uncertain legislative outlook.

stories.headline: Democrats' words against ICE put into public action
stories.summary: Democrats have escalated their rhetoric and actions against ICE, with some Americans threatening and clashing with immigration enforcement agents. Several incidents highlight the rising tensions, including charges against individuals for violent threats and attacks towards ICE officers, reflecting a polarized and confrontational approach to immigration enforcement.

stories.headline: Nominee to lead IRS grilled by senators
stories.summary: A former congressman nominated to lead the IRS faced pointed questions from senators about his lack of background in tax administration and political contributions. The nominee is former U.S. Rep. Billy Long of Missouri, who was questioned about whether the president could legally direct the IRS to take away a taxpayer's tax-exempt status. The discussions reflect broader concerns about the Trump administration's approach to IRS leadership and enforcement.

stories.headline: Some city pools to open just 6 days a week
stories.summary: Baltimore City Department of Recreation and Parks announced that six pools will only be open six days per week in hopes of preserving upgrades, reducing operational strain and maintaining facilities effectively for the community.

stories.headline: Accuser testifies against former Mervo teacher
stories.summary: A 13-year-old girl accused a former Baltimore teacher of rape, testifying before the court that the teacher assaulted her. The case has attracted attention and highlights concerns about abuse in educational settings and the justice process for victims.

stories.headline: Van Hollen, Rubio have heated exchange
stories.summary: Maryland Senator Chris Van Hollen and Senator Marco Rubio engaged in a fiery back-and-forth during a Senate Foreign Relations Committee hearing, debating significant policy differences and showing the partisan tensions in Congress.

stories.headline: Cockeysville man who shot at officers, caused standoff sentenced to life
stories.summary: David Linthicum received two consecutive life sentences plus 30 years for firing at Baltimore County Police officers in 2023 and initiating a multistate manhunt. Linthicum, who was already on life sentences for previous murders, showed little emotion during sentencing. The shooting caused long-term injuries to police officers and deeply impacted victims' families. Linthicum was escorted in and out of the courtroom amid heightened security.

stories.headline: GOP spending bill holdouts unswayed by Trump’s visit
stories.summary: Republican holdouts in the House are reluctant to approve the spending bill despite President Donald Trump's visit to urge support. Congressman Harris expressed optimism about a deal but acknowledged the differences. Other conservative leaders have reservations about the bill's Medicaid and nutritional assistance provisions, and the political implications remain a challenge ahead of the vote.

stories.headline: Moore signs budget with new taxes
stories.summary: Governor Wes Moore signed the state budget and a companion bill that includes roughly $2 billion in spending cuts, $1.6 billion more in tax revenue, and a surplus. The budget implements a 3% tax on tech services while preserving most of the state's Rainy Day Fund and providing $315 million for surplus. Some Republicans opposed the tax-and-spend approach, but the budget aims to deliver a responsible, balanced fiscal plan after negotiations and pressure from political leaders.

stories.headline: Will Baltimore’s marquee festival fly at last or fail?
stories.summary: Baltimore’s 2025 Artscape festival will open Saturday in a new location after moving from its traditional summer spot due to high costs and challenges. The festival operates without a city contract and organizers are downplaying obstacles, emphasizing community involvement and efforts to promote Baltimore's cultural economy. The festival aims to attract people from other states and highlight local arts and culture despite pandemic-related funding challenges.

stories.headline: Matriarch dies after tornado destroys home
stories.summary: Rena Scott-Lyles, a native of St. Louis, died after a tornado destroyed her home in Fountain Park. She and her husband, Allen Lyles, were trapped under the basement wall when their house collapsed. Neighbors helped rescue Allen Lyles from the wreckage. The tornado resulted in tragic loss and trauma for the family amid the severe storm damage.

stories.headline: Teen girl stabbed to death in O'Fallon, Ill.
stories.summary: Cadence Eileen Prince, a high school junior in O'Fallon, Illinois, was tragically stabbed to death at a trailhead over the weekend. Her boyfriend was arrested and charged with murder. Authorities say the attack involved deeply personal motives and the St. Clair County State's Attorney is pursuing charges. The community mourns the loss of the young girl described as kind and adventurous.

stories.headline: Storm alters landscape of Forest Park
stories.summary: The tornado that tore through Forest Park caused significant damage, likely altering the landscape of the popular recreational area. Officials estimate over 1,000 trees were damaged. Forest Park Forever is assessing the damage and strategizing on how to rebuild and rethink the park's landscape while ensuring visitor safety post-storm.

stories.headline: Sharp criticism follows 'failure'
stories.summary: The administration of St. Louis Mayor Cara Spencer faced sharp criticism after the May 16 tornado hit, as officials failed to properly activate outdoor warning sirens that could have saved lives. Spencer vowed transparency but provided few details, amid rising public anger and city officials promising fixes for the siren system failure that left many unalerted during the deadly storm.

stories.headline: New academy gives an inside look at Des Moines’ government
stories.summary: Des Moines has launched a new six-week residential academy, Engage DSM, designed to give residents an insider's view of the city's government operations, including departments, projects, and policies. The program aims to build sustainable relationships between citizens and city officials and educate participants on government functions, with hopes of increasing civic engagement and trust in local government.

stories.headline: Funding bill for schools is signed by governor
stories.summary: Governor Kim Reynolds signed a bill increasing funding for Iowa's K-12 public schools by 2%, resulting in an additional $105 million in state funds plus $21.9 million from other sources. The legislation includes specific allocations for charter schools, transportation equity, and operational sharing, while anticipating further education savings and increased education savings accounts for families in the upcoming school year.

stories.headline: Therapy needs force some kids out of Iowa
stories.summary: Nicole Woodley and other Iowa mothers face challenges when seeking mental health treatments for their children, forcing many families to send their kids out of state due to limited local resources. A new law aims to help by improving access to mental health care and reducing the need for out-of-state treatment, which has been a significant burden for these families.

stories.headline: KC-area instructors warn against cuts to overdose prevention
stories.summary: KC-area instructors, including Ray Rath and Matthew Cushman, emphasize the importance of overdose prevention training for first responders. They warn that budget cuts to such programs could worsen the opioid crisis, as timely and effective response saves lives. Rath and Cushman travel the Kansas City area teaching critical response skills to firefighters, emergency medical technicians, and others. Experts highlight that public education and prevention efforts are vital to reducing overdose deaths.

stories.headline: Kansas nun, 85, takes on Trump, companies for social justice
stories.summary: At 85, Sister Barbara McCracken of Atchison, Kansas, a nun of the Benedictine Sisters of Mount St. Scholastica, actively champions social justice causes. Having protested civil rights issues since the 1960s and opposed the Vietnam War, she has recently spoken out against violence and advocated for vulnerable populations. In 2018, she was arrested during a protest against administration policies. Now, she publicly challenges Donald Trump and corporate actions conflicting with social justice values, gaining renewed attention for her activist stance.

stories.headline: Salina and Cozy Inn clash over mural, free speech rights
stories.summary: An ongoing legal dispute between Salina and a local bar called Cozy Inn has flared over a mural painted at the bar. The city of Salina filed a lawsuit against Cozy Inn owner Steve Howard, claiming the mural violates city codes. Howard counters that the city’s actions infringe on free speech rights. The mural, famed locally, includes local landmarks and playful themes, such as flying saucers and ketchup. The Kansas Justice Institute has joined the case siding with Howard, arguing city restrictions unlawfully limit free speech.

stories.headline: Gainey's Defeat Highlights Era of Political Upheaval
stories.summary: Mayor Ed Gainey's loss in the Democratic primary to Corey O'Connor signifies a major political change in Allegheny County. Gainey, the first Black mayor of Pittsburgh, was defeated amid a larger trend of political shifts in the region, reflecting a period of transformation in local governance and voter sentiment.

stories.headline: Charges Filed in Fan's Fall from the Stands at PNC Park
stories.summary: Ethan Kirkwood, 21, of McKeesport, was charged with buying alcohol for a 20-year-old fan who fell headfirst from the stands at a Pirates game at PNC Park. The incident involved a fall from the 21-foot Clemente Wall during the seventh inning, with medical personnel rushing to aid the injured fan. Kirkwood faced charges related to providing alcohol to a minor and contributing to the incident.

stories.headline: O'Connor Triumphs
stories.summary: Allegheny County Controller Corey O'Connor won Pittsburgh's Democratic mayoral primary, unseating incumbent Mayor Ed Gainey. O'Connor's victory marks a significant political shift in Pittsburgh, with O'Connor gaining about 47% of the vote. The election reflects a desire for change, with the new mayor aiming to bring progress to the city.

stories.headline: Man’s family thought he was safe from drugs inside prison
stories.summary: Clayton Welte was sounding increasingly erratic and incoherent in phone calls to family while serving a drug-related felony sentence at Racine Correctional Institution. Despite family concerns and missed calls, prison staff found Welte unresponsive six weeks into his sentence. The 27-year-old died from an overdose involving fentanyl, heroin, and other drugs. He was one of 21 prison deaths due to drug overdoses since 2014 in Wisconsin, with zero reported since 2024.

stories.headline: Economic impact of RNC at $321M
stories.summary: A study estimated the 2024 Republican National Convention generated more than $200 million in direct spending, including over $50 million by Milwaukee visitors. Along with added business spending, the total economic impact on the local and state economy is estimated at $321 million. This figure includes operational spending supported by a federal grant and encompasses various expenses like event operations, insurance, and professional services.

stories.headline: Two women die in dorm incident at UW-Platteville
stories.summary: Two University of Wisconsin-Platteville students died in a residence hall incident described as a 'targeted and isolated' shooting on May 19. The university identified the students as Kelsie Martin and Hallie Helms, both recently graduated. The incident prompted an emergency evacuation of Wilgus Hall, with students allowed to return to collect belongings after the order was lifted.

stories.headline: Gov. Little’s school ‘wins’ boast has challengers
stories.summary: Idaho Gov. Brad Little celebrated increased funding for public education as a legislative highlight, emphasizing improvements in rural school facilities, teacher salaries, and literacy programs. However, superintendents from various school districts expressed skepticism about the funding's adequacy to address teacher shortages and other systemic issues, with some pushing back against the claim that the session was an overall win for education.

stories.headline: Two dead, no answers: Families seek truth in BIA killings
stories.summary: Cody Whiterock was running for his life when he was shot and killed by Bureau of Indian Affairs police officers in Owyhee County, Idaho. The shooting followed a pursuit and a physical altercation. Whiterock's family continues to grieve and seek answers after nearly two years, as investigations have yet to disclose details about the incident. The family and advocates have faced challenges in obtaining information about the circumstances leading to his death, while another family member's death remains similarly unexplained.

stories.headline: Neighbors wary as luxury builder plans 700 homes in Meridian
stories.summary: Toll Brothers, a luxury home builder, plans to build a 517-home subdivision called Dayspring along with commercial development on 143 acres in Meridian. The proposal also includes 14 lots for retail and offices. Neighbors are concerned as the development would include a mix of single-family homes, town homes, commercial space, and amenities such as parks and pathways. The development has faced skepticism from neighbors about its size and impact.

stories.headline: Higher parking fees, more meters coming to downtown Boise
stories.summary: Boise officials have announced plans to increase metered parking fees, add more parking meters, and expand parking enforcement to improve traffic flow and optimize space usage in downtown Boise. While Sunday parking will remain free, weekday rates will rise from $0.50 to up to $3 per hour within the core of downtown. The city plans to enforce parking from 8 a.m. to 8 p.m. on weekdays, and 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. on Saturdays, aiming to encourage short-term parking and reduce congestion.

stories.headline: IN executes Beech Grove cop killer
stories.summary: Benjamin Ritchie was executed by lethal injection for the 2000 murder of officer William Toney during a traffic stop. The execution took place at the Indiana State Prison in Michigan City. Prior to his death, Ritchie expressed love for his family and friends and hoped they find peace. His legal team had raised issues regarding his diagnosis of fetal alcohol spectrum disorder, which the jury did not accept as mitigating during sentencing. The U.S. Supreme Court denied a stay of execution on May 19.

stories.headline: Medicaid cuts, tax breaks in GOP bill
stories.summary: The House plans to pass a large package with changes to Medicaid, SNAP food benefits, and income taxes aligning with former President Donald Trump's agenda. The bill includes GOP priorities such as energy and border security taxes, new restrictions on benefit programs potentially affecting 7 million people, and efforts by fiscal conservatives to increase cuts as the May 22 vote approaches. Blue-state Republicans oppose parts of the bill and are pushing for state and local tax deductions to be key to the final bill.

stories.headline: 'I didn't kill nobody'
stories.summary: Christopher Thomas was found shot and falling outside his motel room in Elkhart, Indiana. He had left a trail of blood and was wearing only shorts when found. Thomas, a former U.S. Marine and informant for the Elkhart County Drug Task Force, claimed he did not commit murder nor was involved in the crime scene. Police and prosecutors later alleged that key witnesses' testimonies against Reginald Dillard and Eddie Fredrick, two suspects in the case, were fabricated. Investigation revealed no direct physical evidence linking the suspects to the murder.

stories.headline: Officials defend city budget proposal
stories.summary: Mayor Tim Kelly and the Chattanooga City Council’s Budget and Finance Committee have defended a budget proposal amid concerns it may not increase first responders' pay or support council leadership adequately. The administration has a $345.2 million balanced budget proposal after a detailed public hearing, despite some calls for budget cuts. Council members and city staff have discussed the scope and impact of the proposal while facing a challenging budget environment.

stories.headline: 'A scholarship tax'
stories.summary: A Republican proposal to tax elite colleges with large endowments could impact institutions beyond the Ivy League, including smaller schools with sizeable endowments. The tax aims to hold accountable universities operating like major corporations, with an analysis showing at least 58 schools could be subject to the tax. The proposal could particularly affect schools such as McPherson College in Kansas and others like Harvard and Princeton, potentially resulting in significant costs and impacting rural parts of Republican states.

stories.headline: Credit rating for TVA takes hit
stories.summary: The Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA) has lost its perfect credit rating due to rising US debt and deficits, impacting the federally owned energy agency. TVA, which operates electricity for 10 million people, cannot raise money by selling stock and funds major projects through long-term debt, now limited by a $30 billion debt ceiling set by Congress. The rating change affects TVA's financial operations and borrowing capabilities.

stories.headline: Trump urges divided GOP to unify behind his tax cuts bill
stories.summary: President Donald Trump urged House Republicans to unify and support his tax cuts bill during a tense Capitol meeting, emphasizing the need to prevent the $1 trillion-dollar tax cut package from collapsing. He criticized GOP holdouts and praised Speaker Mike Johnson, cautioning lawmakers about the political risks during critical votes. The president also urged not to cut Medicaid and highlighted the importance of the bill to his campaign promises.

stories.headline: ‘They’re going to fight for each other until the end’
stories.summary: The Colby College women's lacrosse team is preparing for the NCAA Division III Final Four, aiming to win the program's first national title. The team will face Middlebury College in the semifinal, with the winner advancing to the championship against either Tufts University or Gettysburg College. Players emphasize their strong team bond and determination to succeed as they approach this historic opportunity.

stories.headline: Justices restore Libby’s right to vote on House floor
stories.summary: The U.S. Supreme Court has ruled in favor of Maine State Representative Laurel Libby, restoring her right to speak and vote on legislation during her lawsuit against the House punishment of her for identifying a transgender student-athlete on social media. The decision overturns the House's censure which prevented Libby from voting, with justices affirming that the legislature cannot silence an elected official simply for speaking about issues that matter. The ruling is seen as a victory for Libby and her constituents who argue her voices were wrongly silenced.

stories.headline: Edward Hopper watercolor of church in Cape Elizabeth sells for $1 million
stories.summary: A 1927 watercolor painting of Spurwink Church by Edward Hopper has sold for $1.016 million to an unidentified European buyer. The painting had been in the same family for over 70 years and was auctioned last week by Sotheby’s. The artwork is notable for capturing the church, the oldest public building in Cape Elizabeth, and is recognized as a significant piece of American art history.

stories.headline: Golden will seek reelection, not run for governor
stories.summary: U.S. Representative Jared Golden, who has represented Maine’s 2nd Congressional District since 2019, announced he will seek another term in Congress rather than running for governor. Golden faces a potential rematch against former Republican Governor Paul LePage in 2026. He is a Lewiston Democrat known for his moderate and bipartisan approach and currently serves on the Democratic State Auditor’s position.

stories.headline: OCI starting expansion
stories.summary: Decatur-based OCI Alabama is beginning a major expansion as it is the only North American producer of a key chemical used in detergents and laundry products. The $19.15 million expansion at its Decatur plant includes new warehouses, silos, expanded railyard and buildings, and installation of unloading and packaging equipment. The company, headquartered in Decatur's Mallard-Fox Creek Industrial Park, employs 65 people and plans to add five more, focusing on infrastructure to pack sodium percarbonate, a key ingredient in detergents such as Tide and Cascade. This is the first phase of an expansion, intended to help store raw materials and finished products more efficiently.

stories.headline: Ladner sets new rules for participation
stories.summary: Three weeks after a turbulent council meeting, Decatur Council President Jacob Ladner announced new rules for public comment to improve decorum and organization during meetings. Public comments will no longer be allowed during sessions held a week prior to formal council meetings but will be accepted during formal meetings on agenda items, at the end of non-agenda meetings, and during legally required public hearings. The rules aim to balance citizens' rights to attend and listen with maintaining orderly council operations after a recent meeting was disrupted by profanity and yelling.

stories.headline: Hugs and smiles for Class of 2025
stories.summary: Austin High School and Decatur High School celebrated their graduation ceremonies with students and families sharing joyful moments. Graduates hugged family members and took selfies to commemorate the occasion, marking a milestone for the Class of 2025 in Decatur, Alabama.

stories.headline: State workers may negotiate telework, salary freezes
stories.summary: The governor is aiming to save $767 million by freezing state workers' salaries to help address California's projected $12 billion deficit. This move depends on negotiations through July 1 and may include reopening agreements with bargaining units to consider telework policy changes and limitations on pay increases. The potential concessions would impact state workers' retirement benefits and reduced retirement payments.

stories.headline: Scientists eye active undersea Axial volcano off Pacific coast
stories.summary: Scientists monitoring the Axial Seamount, an active undersea volcano located about 700 miles northwest of San Francisco, report signs it may erupt by the end of the year. Discovered in the 1980s, this volcano poses little tsunami risk due to its characteristics. The study of Axial Seamount provides insight into volcanic activity and underwater eruptions, which contrast with historical destructive eruptions of other well-known volcanoes such as Mt. Vesuvius and Mt. St. Helens.

stories.headline: Trump squeezes his party on domestic policy bill
stories.summary: President Donald Trump urged House Republicans to unite behind a wide-ranging domestic policy bill called the One Big Beautiful Bill Act. Trump’s efforts to consolidate support emphasize the pressure on the party to bridge internal divisions to pass the bill. He praised Speaker Mike Johnson's efforts to align votes, despite anticipated opposition from Democrats and some Republicans, demonstrating the political challenges ahead for the legislation.

stories.headline: Trial begins for former MLB player accused of murder
stories.summary: Daniel Serafini, a former Major League Baseball pitcher, is on trial for the murder of his in-laws. The prosecution alleges that Serafini killed his wealthy parents-in-law after they confronted him about a reported burglary and tried to pay him to leave the area. Serafini's defense argues no physical evidence links him to the crime and asserts he is not the person seen in the crime video. The case highlights serious accusations involving a known sports figure and the tragic death of family members.

stories.headline: An Album Lost and Found
stories.summary: Grace Potter discusses the making of her LP released after 16 years, highlighting the story and inspiration behind the music.

stories.headline: The Versatility of Sotol
stories.summary: An exploration of Sotol, a traditional spirit from Northern Mexico, and its uses in cocktails and beyond, highlighting cultural and culinary significance.

stories.headline: Time for a Real Gut Check
stories.summary: A discussion on worries about an inflating food stamp program, credit tied to gastrointestinal testing service, and concerns about food security and policy.

stories.headline: Medieval Marvels on Display
stories.summary: The Morgan Library is presenting a 15th-century illuminated manuscript exhibition, showcasing the art and history of medieval culture and literature.

stories.headline: Waiting in the Dark
stories.summary: The Trump administration is trying to claw back climate grants, including $147 million to help Puerto Rico mitigate frequent power failures, raising concerns about climate resilience and aid to vulnerable regions.

stories.headline: Aid Cuts Imperil Africa Trade
stories.summary: President Trump's slashing of foreign assistance threatens African trade and energy projects that are vital to U.S. priorities, putting future diplomatic and economic relations at risk.

stories.headline: F.D.A. Will Sharpen Scrutiny On Who May Need Covid Shot
stories.summary: The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) plans to tighten regulations on Covid-19 vaccinations, focusing on adults over 65 and those with existing health conditions. The agency aims to make booster shots more specifically targeted based on scientific evidence rather than broader distribution. This change follows concerns about unnecessary or uncertain vaccine doses in certain populations.

stories.headline: Tensions Climb as Israel's Allies Condemn Its Escalation in Gaza
stories.summary: Israel's allies have strongly condemned the increasing violence in Gaza and the blockade of humanitarian aid. There are global demands to ease restrictions and prevent a full-scale humanitarian crisis as the conflict continues to escalate, with ongoing diplomatic efforts to find a resolution amid rising casualties and suffering.

stories.headline: How Search for New Air Force One Led Trump to Qatar's Luxury Jet
stories.summary: A story explores the secret coordination between Washington and Doha regarding the purchase of a new Air Force One for President Trump. The decision involved a $3.9 billion contract with Boeing, but delays and negotiations with Qatar over the sale of a luxury jet led to complications. Questions remain about the financial sense and transparency surrounding the deal.

stories.headline: U.S. Embraces Climate Denial In Science Cuts
stories.summary: The Trump administration has taken steps to disregard the economic costs of climate change by limiting scientific research and regulations addressing climate crisis. The administration is reducing funding for climate science and dismantling efforts to chart greenhouse gas buildup and its impacts, raising questions about the government’s response to global warming and environmental risks.

stories.headline: Trump's Shift On Ukraine: You All Fix It
stories.summary: President Trump has shifted responsibility for resolving the Ukraine conflict, signaling a move away from America's three-year-long support for Ukraine. After a phone call between Trump and Vladimir Putin, it appears Trump expects European nations and Ukraine itself to handle the escalating conflict and related sanctions, raising concerns about the US's role in the ongoing war.

stories.headline: Storytelling defines Kendrick Lamar's rise
stories.summary: Kendrick Lamar achieved major success by winning Grammy Awards with his album 'Not Like Us,' which highlights his morals and values. He is notable for being the first rapper to have three albums concurrently in the Billboard Top 10 and won the Pulitzer Prize for Music in 2018. Lamar's current tour with SZA is a defining moment in his career, showcasing his authenticity and connection with hip-hop fans.

stories.headline: ICE's new tactic may be letting perps walk
stories.summary: Some suspects in violent assaults and sex crimes are escaping American justice because they’re being deported before they can stand trial, according to prosecutors and legal experts. In certain cases, ICE agents have detained or deported suspects before prosecution, forcing prosecutors to drop charges. This tactic is causing concern among legal authorities who believe it undermines the justice system and community safety.

stories.headline: Robotaxi fans glad for a ticket to ride
stories.summary: Driverless robotaxis are gaining popularity in San Francisco as a safe and convenient transportation option. Despite initial controversies and safety concerns, too many people now prefer being driven by robotaxis. The rollout of these vehicles continues in cities like Austin, Phoenix, and parts of Silicon Valley, with plans to expand to other major U.S. cities by 2026.

stories.headline: FDA moves to limit COVID vaccinations
stories.summary: The Food and Drug Administration announced it will limit access to COVID-19 vaccines going forward to people 65 and older and others at high risk, reversing the broader qualification for vaccination access. This move follows new guidance and regulatory changes, with the aim of focusing clinical trials on demonstrating benefits for younger and healthier adults. The decision has sparked debate about protection from the virus for the general population.

stories.headline: Healey slammed for shelter contracts
stories.summary: An audit criticized Governor Maura Healey's administration for relying on no-bid contracts in the state's emergency shelter system for migrant and homeless families, leading to high costs and potential overcharges. While officials acknowledged the fast-changing situation, the auditor urged more normal procurement processes between January and August 2023, which the administration had not adequately provided.

stories.headline: ICE tactics draw growing resistance
stories.summary: At a community meeting in Chelsea, immigrant advocates, police, and city officials gathered to express concerns about recent immigration enforcement tactics by ICE, including arrests of women and children without warrants. Protest actions, including videos of arrests and public meetings, show growing community resistance and mobilization against these tactics.

stories.headline: A high-tech lifeline for Macy’s in Boston
stories.summary: Macy’s is closing one-third of its stores as part of a consolidation strategy but will keep 150 stores by the end of next year. For its Downtown Crossing Boston location, the upper floors are being transitioned into a data center as part of a redevelopment by a local real estate developer. This repurposing represents Macy's pivot toward technological infrastructure while maintaining presence in key retail districts.

stories.headline: Officials don’t see savings in search for Medicaid fraud
stories.summary: Despite congressional efforts to reduce Medicaid spending by targeting fraud and waste, experts and officials including deputy Medicaid director Zhao Zhang find it difficult to identify big savings. Medicaid fraud exists but is hard to curtail effectively, and proposed budget cuts pose challenges for people using these services. The cost and administration of Medicaid complicate reform efforts with only modest success in reducing expenses.

stories.headline: Ex-Clinton, Granholm aide accused of antique thefts
stories.summary: A former adviser to ex-Presidents Bill Clinton and Barack Obama, and a high-ranking official for former Michigan Governor Jennifer Granholm, is accused of stealing a porcelain sign and showing remorse when caught. Tom Kerr, the accused, did not fully come clean and allegedly sold the sign for $400 while trying to make amends.

stories.headline: 'CHEERS' star George Wendt dies at 76
stories.summary: George Wendt, famously known for his role in the television series 'Cheers,' has passed away at the age of 76. His death marks the loss of a beloved actor recognized for his iconic TV character and contributions to entertainment.

stories.headline: Trump warns GOP to get behind his 'big' bill
stories.summary: President Donald Trump urged Capitol Hill to support his agenda, including a controversial immigration bill, during his visit with House Republicans. With a narrow majority in the House, Trump emphasized unity among Republicans for faster progress on his legislative proposals, including the House Budget Committee bill. Despite procedural obstacles, Trump remains optimistic about meeting deadlines and advancing his agenda.

stories.headline: Boy Scouts abuse probe closes with 1 conviction
stories.summary: After a four-year investigation into the Boy Scouts of America sexual abuse scandal, there has been one conviction. Mark Chapman, aged 55, pleaded guilty to sexual assault crimes from the 1970s. The probe faced challenges due to lack of complainants and the unique environment of the organization. The case highlighted the complexity and continued issues related to abuse within the Boy Scouts.

stories.headline: Senate to vote on voiding Calif. emissions rules
stories.summary: The U.S. Senate is set to vote on overturning California's stringent regulations requiring 100% electric vehicles by 2035. The move, supported by Senate Republicans, challenges California's authority on vehicle emissions and threatens efforts to electrify fleets nationally, with implications for the auto industry and economy. Michigan is not part of the states that adopted California's standards but faces potential market impacts over the next decade.

stories.headline: Johnson: 'I've done my part' on Bears
stories.summary: Mayor Brandon Johnson stated he has done everything he can to lobby lawmakers to secure state funding to keep the Bears in Chicago, even as the team is looking to move to Arlington Heights. He acknowledged the decision lies with Springfield and indicated he may not be able to influence the outcome further.

stories.headline: From Second City troupe to fame on TV's 'Cheers'
stories.summary: George Wendt, a native of Chicago's South Side and actor famous for his role on the TV show 'Cheers,' passed away at age 76. He was known for his contributions to improvisational comedy with the Second City troupe and his enduring influence in television and stage productions. Wendt was celebrated for his humor and his connection to his Chicago roots.

stories.headline: Pope failed to 'properly investigate' child sex abuse, victims group alleges
stories.summary: A victims group accused Pope Leo XIV of neglecting to properly investigate abuse claims involving children, amid allegations of mismanaged multiple cases of sexual abuse by Catholic priests in Chicago. The group emphasized the church’s failure to protect children and highlighted the responsibility of leaders in addressing these serious issues.

stories.headline: AmeriCorps cuts leave kids programs in limbo
stories.summary: AmeriCorps, a nonprofit organization supporting programs for children experiencing homelessness and housing insecurity, faces funding cuts and program terminations due to federal budget constraints and the Trump administration's reduced government spending. These changes jeopardize summer programming and volunteer opportunities for many disadvantaged youth served by AmeriCorps in Illinois and across the country.

stories.headline: For Pa. primary, many elected to stay home
stories.summary: The primary election for Philadelphia District Attorney showed low voter turnout, with many elected officials and voters staying home. The contest between Larry Krasner and challenger Patrick Dugan did not mobilize enough voters in this off-year primary, with observers noting slow and low interest at the polls. Omar Sabir, chair of the city commissioners, said many candidates appeared on track for easier reelection in 2026 due to the low engagement.

stories.headline: New Guidelines Shift Who Should Get COVID Vaccine
stories.summary: The Food and Drug Administration updated its vaccine guidelines to narrow approval for COVID-19 vaccines to older adults and those with high-risk health conditions, such as diabetes or cancer. This significant change shifts the focus of vaccination towards those over 65 and people with severe disease risks, with an estimated 100 million Americans becoming eligible under the new framework. However, it remains unclear if healthy people under 65 will receive vaccines for free, with decisions ultimately left to the CDC's advisory panel.

stories.headline: Trump prods, threatens GOP to back budget bill
stories.summary: President Donald Trump pressured the Republican Party to support his budget bill aimed at tax and immigration reforms, pushing House Republicans to hasten legislation despite reservations. The bill is key to Trump's agenda but faces opposition from hard-line GOP members concerned about spending. House Speaker Mike Johnson and leadership are working to advance the bill amid intra-party tensions.

stories.headline: Surgical Patient is Asked: 'Are you a U.S. citizen?'
stories.summary: Pamela Albright, a Wisconsin native, reported being asked about her U.S. citizenship status during her appointment at Temple Hospital for presurgery testing. Albright stressed that the inquiry caused her distress. Temple Hospital has stated it does not ask about citizenship during intake, and a spokesperson suggested the question might have been asked mistakenly. The incident is under review to determine if there was a breach of protocol.

stories.headline: Cuts mean fewer eyes on twisters
stories.summary: The National Weather Service is facing staffing cuts due to Department of Government Efficiency, impacting its ability to monitor tornadoes effectively. This comes as the U.S. experiences increasing tornado activity, with forecasters warning of a busy season. Staffing shortages have already led to closures of some offices and reliance on overtime, raising concerns among meteorologists and officials about maintaining adequate storm tracking and public safety measures during severe weather events.

stories.headline: House passes tax cut bills
stories.summary: The Texas House has overwhelmingly approved legislation to raise the homestead exemption for property tax from $100,000 to $140,000 and add an additional $60,000 exemption for older Texans and those with disabilities. The measures, part of a $10 billion property tax relief package, aim to ease the tax burden on homeowners and will next be considered by the Senate. The bills come after months of negotiation among lawmakers and are expected to benefit many Texans through increased exemptions and property tax relief.

stories.headline: Safety, but not sterility: More police raises more questions
stories.summary: Dallas officials plan to increase police presence downtown by about 35 officers, raising department staffing to its highest level in a decade, amid efforts to improve public safety without creating a sterile environment. The city aims to balance enforcement and public perception while tackling safety challenges including homelessness through a public-private partnership involving Downtown Dallas Inc. The initiative includes upgrading technology such as 10 surveillance cameras and emphasizes collaboration with private businesses to enhance quality of life and safety in the city core.

stories.headline: Migrants Stay on Job Despite Crackdown
stories.summary: President Trump’s administration faces challenges in deporting migrants, as many continue to work despite efforts to enforce immigration laws. Employers find it difficult to comply with restrictive status verification requirements while migrants remain on the job. The crackdown faces implementation hurdles and labor market complexities.

stories.headline: Netanyahu Confronts Pressure From Allies To End War in Gaza
stories.summary: Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu is under pressure from allies including the U.S., Canada, and Britain to end the war in Gaza while continuing efforts against Hamas. Allies are urging for a restrained approach amid international concern about the conflict’s humanitarian impact. The Israeli government signals intent for a strong military campaign while balancing diplomatic and political pressures.

stories.headline: President Tells GOP Dissenters To Drop Objections
stories.summary: President Trump warned Republicans who oppose his agenda that they risk political consequences as the party seeks to push through tax relief and spending policies, including Medicaid and SALT cap reforms. He signaled waning patience with GOP dissenters during a closed-door meeting and urged fiscal conservatives to support key proposals to avoid undermining the party’s unified stance.

stories.headline: Google Takes Aim at AI Rivals on Search
stories.summary: Google is overhauling its search engine to compete more directly with AI-powered chatbots that threaten its core business. The change marks Google's most ambitious effort to confront AI upstarts that challenge its flagship search product and largest source of revenue. Google is developing new AI-powered features in its search to maintain its market leadership amid rising competition.

stories.headline: Europe’s Firms Fall Far Behind In the Race to Create Big Tech
stories.summary: Europe is falling behind in the technology sector, lacking homegrown alternatives to major American companies like Meta, Apple, and Amazon. The continent’s technology revolution is losing pace due to stagnant economic growth, risk-averse business culture, strict labor laws, and demographic challenges. Investors and entrepreneurs are struggling to foster significant big technology firms in Europe, which impacts the continent’s future economic strength and global competitiveness.

stories.headline: GOP bill puts Ariz. health coverage at risk, Dems warn
stories.summary: Democrats warn that a Republican reconciliation bill could cause more than 300,000 Arizonans to lose their health insurance. The bill, which is making its way through Congress, proposes cutting hundreds of millions from the federal budget and removing a 2017 tax break passed during the Trump administration. Senator Mark Kelly highlights concerns from families across Arizona worried about losing essential health care coverage.

stories.headline: AZ officer defends 'tool' for eviction
stories.summary: Teim Zehring, a crime prevention officer with the Mesa Police Department, supports a crime-free lease addendum allowing landlords to take action against tenants engaged in criminal activity. Zehring believes empowering landlords to handle such issues independently can reduce the burden on law enforcement agencies. The addendum is a voluntary agreement within Arizona, aimed at providing landlords broad discretion to evict tenants with crime histories. Zehring's stance comes amidst criticism of the tool's impact.

stories.headline: WATER EVASION
stories.summary: Border Patrol Agent Justin Castrejon observes smugglers using boats to circumvent border enforcement between the U.S. and Mexico. Despite the Trump administration's crackdown reducing migrant apprehensions, smugglers resort to maritime routes to evade detection. A recent incident resulted in the tragic drowning of three migrants, including children, after a boat capsized near Del Mar, California. Castrejon emphasizes the human risk involved, noting smugglers treat people as cargo rather than humans.

stories.headline: Fort Bend ISD could close or consolidate 19 grade schools
stories.summary: Facing demographic shifts and budget shortfalls, Fort Bend ISD is considering closing or consolidating 19 elementary campuses due to declining enrollment and financial constraints estimated at a $13 million budget gap for the next school year. Auditors and district officials are reviewing options to reduce costs including possible campus closures or consolidations next year. The move could save funds but also means fewer school choices for students and families, as well as logistical challenges. The district aims to balance budget needs while planning for optimal educational delivery within available resources.

stories.headline: Bail bills Abbott promoted pass House
stories.summary: The Texas House approved restrictive bail measures long sought by Governor Greg Abbott, which will be put on the November ballot for voters to decide as constitutional amendments. The amendments aim to strengthen judges' power to deny bail to certain accused criminals, keeping them behind bars until trial. The approval is seen as a political victory for Abbott and supporters, despite criticism from Houston Democrats who argue that the laws reduce protections for defendants accused of violent offenses. The legislation also faces some debate over concerns about pretrial release policies and their social impact.

stories.headline: ‘Heartbreaking’ cuts hollow out HISD libraries
stories.summary: Houston ISD is undergoing significant cuts, reducing its librarian staff to 23 for 274 schools as part of a rebuilt central office team led by Superintendent Mike Miles. This reduction means less support for school libraries statewide, weakening services that were once provided by more librarians including those in district and neighboring schools. Advocates and volunteers are working to support libraries despite these challenges. The cuts reflect a heart-wrenching blow to community members and educators invested in equitable educational resources and access across Houston ISD.

stories.headline: DA dismisses charges against Hotze
stories.summary: The Harris County District Attorney's Office has ended its prosecution against Republican activist Steven Hotze, dismissing four felony charges related to an alleged conspiracy-fueled assault on an AC repairman in 2020. The DA's office also announced dropping three of five charges against Mark Aguirre, Hotze’s private investigator. District Attorney Sean Teare called the attack a "baseless voter fraud conspiracy scheme" and emphasized that prosecutors could not stand by the indictments implicating Hotze. The case showed how conspiracy theories can fuel real-world violence, but the DA stressed the pursuit of facts over political theater and media spectacle.

stories.headline: When apples fall too far from factory
stories.summary: Manzana Products Co., a major apple processing plant in Sebastopol, is relocating to Washington due to the decline of apple harvests in Sonoma County and the Bay Area orchards. The company, which started nearly a century ago, has seen dwindling local apple supplies, affecting its operations and prompting the move to Yakima County, Washington to continue processing apples and related products.

stories.headline: DA opens probe into nonprofit’s finances
stories.summary: The San Francisco District Attorney's office has launched a criminal investigation into the finances of the San Francisco Parks Alliance over allegations of misappropriation of at least $3.8 million. The inquiry follows revelations of financial mismanagement, including improper spending of restricted funds and donations, with the case being handled by the DA's public integrity unit as part of a broader probe into city-related nonprofits.

stories.headline: Watchdog says patients were abused at hospital
stories.summary: Disability Rights California released a report confirming that a for-profit psychiatric hospital in Southern California abused patients for years by excessively restraining and improperly administering drugs, violating federal and state regulations. The report focused on patient care at College Hospital in Cerritos and highlights serious concerns about mistreatment in psychiatric facilities.

stories.headline: Private equity increases holdings in Napa Valley’s wine industry
stories.summary: Private equity firms have been actively investing in California wineries, especially in the Napa Valley, targeting renowned estates such as Duckhorn Portfolio and Far Niente Wine Estates. This trend reflects a strategic move to quickly acquire and grow wine businesses, with these new investors reshaping the ownership landscape in the region’s prestigious wine industry.

stories.headline: State Farm eyes higher rate after emergency hike
stories.summary: State Farm General is seeking regulatory approval for an additional increase in home insurance rates after a recent emergency hike of 17% following widespread fires in Los Angeles. Initially requesting a 30% rate increase in June 2024, the insurer now aims to revert to this original request pending approval. The adjustments are intended to address the heightened risk and costs associated with recent emergency conditions.

stories.headline: FOR ROCHESTER, A 'BUMPY RIDE'
stories.summary: Rochester city officials and Mayo Clinic leaders are discussing an ambitious $585 million plan to build a new international medical hub by 2030. The project involves significant renovations including a nearly $20 million upgrade to Peace Plaza, a key attraction in downtown Rochester. Local reactions are mixed, with some residents wary of the impact and disruption from the extensive construction and changes.

stories.headline: Cryptocurrency investors buy an evening with Trump
stories.summary: An exclusive dinner event featuring former President Donald Trump was auctioned off to a group of around 60 cryptocurrency investors from China and Southeast Asia, who bid millions of dollars. The event is part of a broader push by Trump supporters to capitalize on the growing crypto market. The organizers hope to expand business ventures and influence through this unique fundraiser.

stories.headline: Calif. evidence inadmissible in trial for 5-fatality crash
stories.summary: The Minnesota Court of Appeals ruled that certain evidence in the murder conviction of a man involved in a 5-fatality car crash in California is inadmissible. The trial, related to a high-profile case with overlapping criminal and civil proceedings, highlights complexities in courtroom rules and may impact the outcome of this serious vehicular homicide case.

stories.headline: FDA to limit use of COVID vaccines
stories.summary: The Food and Drug Administration announced it will restrict the use of COVID vaccines for adults older than 65 and those with certain medical conditions to the fall, requiring additional studies for approval for other groups. This decision comes amid concerns over the vaccines' benefits for younger and middle-aged people who have already been vaccinated or had COVID. Health officials emphasize the need for robust data to guide vaccine use moving forward.

stories.headline: Budget tussling is off to slow start
stories.summary: Minnesota lawmakers are unlikely to reconvene until the end of the week at the earliest due to narrow legislative divisions. The state is trying to finalize a $66 billion budget, but partisan conflicts and unrelated policy proposals have delayed progress. A special session could occur Thursday or Friday to address the budget before the fiscal year begins on July 1, aiming to avoid government shutdowns and keep state operations funded.

stories.headline: Athletes sue Ellison, state leaders
stories.summary: Three high school softball players are suing Minnesota Attorney General Keith Ellison and other state leaders to remove transgender athletes from their sport. The lawsuit focuses on an unsafe and unfair environment for female high school players and challenges current policies allowing transgender athletes to compete in girls' sports. Ellison was also sued in April for allegedly bullying trans children. This legal action highlights the ongoing debate over transgender athletes' participation in school sports.

stories.headline: Trump backs off ceasefire effort after call with Putin
stories.summary: Following a call between President Trump and Russian President Vladimir Putin, Trump backed off earlier efforts to push Russia into a ceasefire and toward peace in Ukraine. Despite diplomatic efforts and encouragement from European leaders, Trump indicated a shift in stance, reflecting the complex and evolving nature of the conflict and negotiations with Russia.

stories.headline: President lauds, warns 'unified' GOP on budget bill
stories.summary: President Donald Trump urged unity among Republicans on the massive tax and immigration budget bill, emphasizing the importance of regaining momentum on his second-term plans. He warned and pressed Capitol Hill to avoid holdouts and keep his agenda moving through the House Budget Committee amid moderate and conservative tensions.

stories.headline: DHS bid would relocate migrants
stories.summary: The Trump administration has proposed spending up to $250 million to relocate foreign assistance to fund the removal and return of people from active conflict zones, including 700,000 Ukrainian and Haitian migrants who fled to the United States. This plan includes executive endurance back home and aims to self-deport those eligible for aid, raising considerable political and humanitarian debates.

stories.headline: 'We want to put them in trauma'
stories.summary: A federal worker detailing the effects of Trump's second-term agenda on government employees described panic attacks, depression, and suicidal thoughts among workers. The article highlights the emotional and mental toll on federal employees amid tough working conditions, showing a harsh impact on their well-being and a growing sense of distress in the workforce.

stories.headline: Camera network secretly aided New Orleans police
stories.summary: New Orleans police secretly relied on a facial recognition technology network for two years, allowing 200 facial recognition cameras to monitor streets and send alerts to officers. The system used private networks and mobile phones to convey relevant locations of possible suspects. Amid civil rights concerns and a 2022 city council ordinance limiting facial recognition use, the police have paused the system after records requests by The Washington Post.

stories.headline: FDA might limit access to shots for coronavirus
stories.summary: The Food and Drug Administration plans to narrow its approval for updated coronavirus vaccines to older adults and people with at least one health condition putting them at higher risk for severe disease. This approach marks a shift in the agency's policy, likely making updated vaccines available mostly to Americans over 65 and people with other health vulnerabilities, aiming to address safety concerns and maximize vaccine effectiveness.

stories.headline: Incendiary path to fertility clinic bombing
stories.summary: A suspect in a blast at a fertility clinic in Palm Springs, who also burned down his family home, was fascinated by explosives. Authorities found videos of explosives use and a YouTube site that law enforcement officials believed belonged to the suspect, showing a possible single one-elem bomb in a modern male youth's war games video game clip. On Saturday, a bomb detonated at the fertility clinic, and the suspect, Guy Bartkus, is linked by evidence and voice capture to the attack, which tragically killed one worker and was an act of domestic terrorism. DNA and investigative leads are pointing to Bartkus as the suspect.

stories.headline: Trump’s tariffs renew concerns about GM’s future in South Korea
stories.summary: Trump administration's 25% tariff on imported cars and trucks from South Korea is causing anxiety about General Motors' viability as an exporter to the Asian nation. GM, which operates significant factories and employs many workers in South Korea, faces potential loss of sales and market challenges. South Korea is a major market for GM, and the tariffs, part of broader trade tensions between the U.S. and South Korea, impact the automotive industry with possible shifts in production and exports.

stories.headline: Soccer superfans bench themselves
stories.summary: Following local ICE raids in Nashville, Latino aficionados of Nashville SC are skipping soccer matches out of fear. This has led to an unusual quiet at the club's home matches; groups that typically bring energy to the stands have reduced their presence. The impact is significant on the fanbase and adds to the sociopolitical challenges facing the community around the club.

stories.headline: Firm restarts oil drill off the coast
stories.summary: Sable Offshore Corp. has resumed oil extraction and disputed the authority of the California Coastal Commission. The decision follows almost 10 years after a massive oil spill polluted the Santa Barbara coastline and halted several drilling platforms. Sable's announcement came one month after the Coastal Commission ordered the company to stop work due to failing to meet permits and reviews. Environmentalists and state and local officials decried the move, fearing harm to sensitive habitats and the environment. The Trump administration supports expanded fossil fuel production, encouraging oil and gas activity along the coast.

stories.headline: Trump seeks to save his big bill
stories.summary: President Trump implored House Republicans to drop their fights over his big tax-cut bill and get it done, using encouraging words despite the hardening language of politics over the multitrillion-dollar package that is at risk of collapsing before planned votes this week. Trump warned Republicans not to touch Medicaid with cuts, urged New York lawmakers to end their fight for a bigger local tax deduction, reversing his own campaign promise. He positioned himself as a "cheerleader" for the Republican Party and praised Speaker Mike Johnson but criticized some GOP holdouts as a "grandstander" and warned anyone opposing the bill would be a "fool."

stories.headline: Trump squeezes his party on domestic policy bill
stories.summary: President Donald Trump pressured House Republicans on Capitol Hill to support a domestic agenda package despite some resistance within his party. He urged unity to pass the One Big Beautiful Bill Act, which includes provisions on tax cuts, military and immigration enforcement funding, Medicaid, and environmental subsidies. Although some Republicans expressed concerns regarding parts of the bill and potential corporate tax increases, Trump emphasized the importance of cutting waste fraud and abuse and maintaining benefits.

stories.headline: NWS responds to questions about staffing, storm alerts
stories.summary: This article discusses Kentucky's challenges with short staffing at the National Weather Service's Jackson office, which covers hard-hit areas like Laurel and Pulaski counties. The shortage impacts the office's ability to issue timely alerts, including for the deadly storms on Friday night. It explains the types of alerts issued, the office's typical staffing levels, and the efforts by other NWS offices to step in and assist.

stories.headline: Deadly storms hit Laurel County
stories.summary: A tornado swept across Southern Kentucky on Friday, May 20, 2025, hitting the Sunshine Hills area of Laurel County particularly hard. The storm resulted in at least 19 fatalities across three counties: 17 in Laurel County, 1 in Pulaski County, and 1 in Russell County. The destruction was captured visually, showing severe damage to the community and infrastructure.

stories.headline: Who were the 19 victims of storms in southeast KY?
stories.summary: This story profiles the known victims of deadly storms that hit southeastern Kentucky, specifically in Laurel, Pulaski, and Russell counties. It provides tributes and condolences for those who lost their lives, detailing their relationships, community roles, and the impact of the tragedy on their families and local residents. Among the victims highlighted are Richard "Dickie" McFall, Wanda McFall, and June Fisher—each remembered for their contributions to family, community, and faith.

stories.headline: FDA to shrink range of approval for COVID shot
stories.summary: The Food and Drug Administration announced plans to narrow its approval for updated COVID-19 vaccines, recommending them only for those 65 or older or those with certain health conditions. This shift aims to address vulnerability in high-risk groups and reflects updated analysis on vaccine protection. The decision could limit vaccine availability for the broader public but ensures targeted protection for those most at risk from severe illness.

stories.headline: Resort’s ability to evaluate effluent disputed on final day of hearing
stories.summary: At the final day of hearings for Bishop’s Lodge wastewater permit, the resort’s capacity to evaluate luxury resort wastewater treatment plans was challenged. Testimonies from Environment Department employees and community members illustrated concerns about the adequacy of the resort's testing methods. The hearing followed hours of testimony and aimed to address opposition to the resort’s proposed wastewater use to pump effluent to a municipal water plant.

stories.headline: Hacker steals $324K from city; it may not be recoverable
stories.summary: A cyberattack infiltrated an online payment portal and diverted $324,000 intended for a roadwork contractor. City officials were notified after Wells Fargo flagged suspicious account activity. Investigation involves the Santa Fe Police Department and law enforcement including the FBI. Due to delays in notification and potential fraudulent accounts, it remains unclear if stolen funds can be recovered. The incident highlights vulnerabilities in municipal cyber security.

stories.headline: Plea deal for one guard in shooting
stories.summary: One of two former security guards accused of ambushing a couple sleeping in their truck faces between four to 14 years in jail following a plea deal. Luis Adrian Garcia's fate will be decided by a judge after a diagnostic period. Garcia and co-defendant Jair Rascon-Chavez were charged with attempted murder and related offenses after a November incident at an Albertsons store. Security guards allegedly fired assault rifles and wounded a man during the event.

stories.headline: Gov.’s civility claims fall flat with opponents
stories.summary: In Democratic Gov. Michelle Lujan Grisham's first legislative session in 2019, she swiftly signed nearly four dozen bills her predecessor, Republican Gov. Susana Martinez, had vetoed despite bipartisan support. Lujan Grisham hosted an event on political civility emphasizing cooperation and political goodwill, but ex-lawmaker critics believe her civility claims are a narrative not reflected in reality, noting partisan battles and a lack of genuine bipartisanship.

stories.headline: Trump honors three PBSO deputies killed in crash
stories.summary: President Donald Trump honored the three Palm Beach County Sheriff's Office motorcycle deputies who died in a November roadside crash at the White House on May 19, making them the first recipients of the Medal of Sacrifice. The medal is awarded posthumously to law enforcement officers and other first responders killed in the line of duty. Trump presented the medals to the families of Corporal Luis Paez and deputies Ralph "Butch" Waller and Ignacio "Dan" Diaz, who died after an SUV struck them. The Florida Highway Patrol is investigating the crash. Trump praised the deputies' commitment to protecting the community and emphasized the importance of remembering their legacy and debt owed to law enforcement heroes.

stories.headline: PBC judge unleashed serial killer who preyed on girls across U.S.
stories.summary: About 20 years before Jeffrey Epstein's crimes became public, a Palm Beach County judge missed an opportunity to stop serial killer Christopher Wilder, who then went on to abduct and kill multiple underage girls across the United States. The judge allowed Wilder to go free despite his documented predatory and sexual assault behaviors, enabling him to kidnap and kill several victims, including young girls abducted in 1983 and 1984. Wilder preyed on teenage girls and undertook a killing rampage that shocked the country. The judge's failure to lock him up earlier raised questions about justice and accountability.

stories.headline: Eliminating ACA subsidies would strike Florida hard
stories.summary: An estimated 4 million Floridians receive their health insurance through the Affordable Care Act and could see their premiums rise dramatically by the end of 2025 if House Republicans' budget bill eliminates ACA subsidies. Florida has one of the highest proportions of residents receiving health care through the ACA Marketplace, with 20 out of every 100 Floridians enrolled. Most enrollees receive subsidies that help pay for their premiums, so ending these would significantly impact many residents.

stories.headline: Trump: Leave Medicaid alone
stories.summary: President Donald Trump warned House Republicans not to reduce Medicaid funding further, urging lawmakers to support his 'big, beautiful bill' focused on domestic agenda priorities. Trump emphasized focusing on eliminating waste, fraud, and abuse within Medicaid rather than deeper cuts, responding to pressure from the far-right House Freedom Caucus. The proposed bill aims to cut an estimated $625 billion from Medicaid over ten years but provide health care to more than 71 million low-income Americans. Trump expressed hope that the legislation would pass without contentious primary challenges and rejected tax changes or a state and local tax provision.

stories.headline: Duffy vows to reinforce English-only trucking
stories.summary: U.S. Transportation Secretary Sean Duffy signed a proclamation enforcing a 'common sense' safety standard requiring commercial truck drivers to be proficient in English. This executive order, directed by President Trump, aims to improve safety by ensuring drivers can read road signs, communicate with law enforcement, and understand traffic signs. The proclamation comes after several incidents, including one involving a truck driver with questionable English skills. This policy will take effect on June 25 and has been announced at the Texas Department of Transportation headquarters in Austin.

stories.headline: UT loses $47M in research funds
stories.summary: The University of Texas College of Liberal Arts lost $47 million in federal research funding due to the termination or stopping of 67 projects by the federal government. This includes a $250,000 research grant awarded to associate professor Danielle Clealand for historical immigration research. The federal agency did not provide explanations for the cutbacks, which have significantly impacted various academic disciplines at UT. The cuts occurred during the Trump administration and resulted in a halt of $52 million in research funding by the federal government, with only four projects regaining funding as of the report date.

stories.headline: Eviction day has passed, and these Sweetwater holdouts refuse to leave
stories.summary: Santos Varela and others in Sweetwater's Li'l Abner Mobile Home Park are refusing to leave their homes despite a January 31 deadline and offers to buy out their park ownership. Varela is dealing with chemotherapy and eviction threats as the park owner CREI Holdings plans to redevelop the property. The situation remains tense amid complaints of an unfair eviction process impacting long-standing residents.

stories.headline: Supreme Court ruling raises questions even as it lets Venezuelans be sent back home
stories.summary: Following the Supreme Court's decision to revoke Temporary Protected Status for Venezuelans, significant uncertainty remains around how the order will be enforced and its broader implications. The ruling lifts a federal judge's order blocking deportation plans, but the Department of Homeland Security and appeals courts are expected to see ongoing reviews. The decision leaves many Venezuelan immigrants concerned about the future of their immigration status and work permits.

stories.headline: State prosecutor’s office launches criminal investigation related to Hope Florida
stories.summary: Leon County prosecutors have launched a criminal investigation regarding information linked to the Hope Florida Foundation amid allegations by House Republicans. The probe looks into potential illegal diversion of $10 million from a Medicaid contractor linked to the foundation, supported by Gov. Ron DeSantis and first lady Casey DeSantis. This investigation follows requests by lawmakers and scrutiny over the foundation's dealings.

stories.headline: Supreme Court ruling on TPS stuns South Florida, leaves Venezuelan families in fear
stories.summary: A U.S. Supreme Court decision allowing the Trump administration to strip deportation protections and work permits from hundreds of thousands of Venezuelans has shocked South Florida's large Venezuelan population. The ruling means protections for Venezuelan immigrants under Temporary Protected Status could end, despite their established community and improved living conditions back home. This has caused widespread fear among families about potential deportation and separation.

stories.headline: Getting away for Memorial Day? You betcha.
stories.summary: An estimated 3.6 million Americans are expected to fly over the Memorial Day weekend, nearly 2% more than last year despite economic concerns and high gas prices. Many are opting to drive to their destinations amid fuel costs averaging $3.18 per gallon. Airlines and travel sectors are seeing strong holiday travel numbers with an increase in both air and road travel, although the outlook for air travel remains somewhat uncertain due to flight delays and cancellations caused by staffing shortages and equipment failures.

stories.headline: Gov. requests federal disaster aid for northern ice damage
stories.summary: Governor Gretchen Whitmer has formally requested federal aid from President Donald Trump to help northern Michigan communities recover and rebuild from significant ice storm damage that occurred in March. The disaster declaration, if approved, would unlock millions in federal aid to assist families, small businesses, and communities in the affected areas. The storms caused widespread power outages, blocked roadways, and damaged property, totaling an estimated $137 million in damage according to Michigan State Police assessments.

stories.headline: AG says Benson broke campaign finance law with announcement
stories.summary: Secretary of State Jocelyn Benson violated Michigan's campaign finance law when she used a state-owned building to announce her run for governor, according to Attorney General Dana Nessel. However, Benson won't face fines or misdemeanor charges as the state law does not give the attorney general authority to punish her. The AG's Opinions Division emphasized a warning to the secretary of state to adhere to campaign finance rules to avoid future violations, with a campaign spokesperson noting a new interpretation of the law related to such announcements.

stories.headline: Feds to ditch paper checks for payouts
stories.summary: The federal government plans to phase out paper checks for payments this fall, moving towards electronic payments following a March executive order by President Donald Trump. This shift, welcomed by financial experts but cautioned against for potential unintended consequences, aims to safeguard taxpayer dollars and improve payment efficiency. However, concerns remain about the impact on individuals without bank accounts who rely on paper checks for tax returns and government benefits.

stories.headline: 7.6M in U.S. may lose their health insurance
stories.summary: The House is considering a massive GOP tax package including changes to Medicaid and SNAP food benefits, aligned with President Donald Trump's agenda. The package could cause more than 7 million people to lose federal health care coverage. Fiscal conservatives are pushing for more cuts ahead of a key vote while some blue-state Republicans push for state and local tax deduction policies. The final vote and package details are still pending, with slim margins on the bill making its passage uncertain.

stories.headline: Employees at metro Detroit nursing homes walk off job
stories.summary: Nursing home workers at five Ciena Healthcare sites in Detroit, West Bloomfield, and St. Clair Shores participated in a one-day labor strike due to ongoing contentious contract negotiations between the company and SEIU Healthcare Michigan. The strike involved about 300 workers who cited lack of adequate supplies, understaffing, and challenges due to working without contracts for several months. The workers are asking for higher wages, paid sick time, holidays, and improvements to health insurance coverage.

stories.headline: LR board weighs plan to save complex
stories.summary: The Little Rock Board of Directors discussed a proposal for a $75 million loan to save the Madison Heights apartments, a large affordable housing complex in need of repairs and improvements. The plan aims to preserve 301 mixed-market and federally assisted housing units and prevent residents from being displaced, while addressing infrastructure and resolution needs related to foreclosure.

stories.headline: State Medicaid work requisite cited as warning
stories.summary: U.S. House members expressed concerns about work requirements for Medicaid programs in Arkansas and other states, noting that judicial overrulings and administrative policies could create barriers for recipients. Democratic lawmakers worry that the requirement to work or volunteer could endanger benefits for vulnerable populations, and the effort has sparked significant political debate.

stories.headline: Approval for covid shot to be narrowed
